importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of publication marks the latest update in the diplomatic and aviation developments between China and India, signaling a renewed engagement between the two nations after a five-year suspension of direct flights.

The announcement of flight resumption on November 9, 2025, is tied to the current date of publication, indicating that the news is timely and reflects a current diplomatic and logistical shift in Sino-Indian relations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Direct flights between India and China were suspended during the COVID pandemic in 2020, marking a critical turning point in bilateral air connectivity and relations.
The resumption of flights in 2025 reflects a broader diplomatic thaw between India and China, indicating a renewed focus on economic cooperation and regional stability.

keyTakeAways: China Eastern Airlines will resume Shanghai-Delhi flights starting November 9, 2025, after a five-year freeze.
The flight resumption is part of a broader diplomatic thaw between China and India, prompted by tensions from U.S. trade policies and shared regional security concerns.
Flights will operate three times weekly on Wednesdays, Saturdays, and Sundays, signaling a return to commercial air connectivity.
The move follows Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s first visit to China in over seven years, during which trade and security issues were discussed.
India's largest carrier, IndiGo, previously announced daily flights between Kolkata and Guangzhou, indicating a broader trend toward increased regional air links.
The diplomatic thaw occurs amid U.S. President Donald Trump’s aggressive trade policies, including 50% tariffs on Indian imports and calls for 100% tariffs on China and India.
Direct flights were suspended due to deadly border clashes in 2020, which resulted in the deaths of four Chinese and 20 Indian soldiers.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China Eastern Airlines is resuming direct flights between Shanghai and Delhi starting November 9, 2025, after a five-year suspension. This development is part of a broader diplomatic thaw between India and China, following Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s first visit to China in over seven years. The flight resumption—operating three times weekly—marks a significant step in restoring commercial and diplomatic ties, especially amid rising U.S. trade tensions and previous border violence in 2020. The move is also supported by India’s IndiGo and Chinese airport authorities, who have encouraged more direct routes. The diplomatic shift is seen as a strategic response to U.S. trade policies, including Trump’s proposed 50% tariff on Indian goods and 100% tariffs on China and India, which are shaping regional economic and security dynamics.
title: China Eastern Airlines to resume flights to India after five-year freeze
